Model.Name: Smart City Concept Model
Model.Description: A city, wishing to share data between organisations and with its citizens, will want to use consistent identifiers to refer to the same thing.

Concept.Name: Abstract
Concept.Definition: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical existence.
Concept.Examples: * Fear of Crime * Knowledge

Concept.Name: Account
Concept.Definition: A container of information, held by an AGENT, in which to record data arising from EVENTs that relate to an ITEM in a role.
Concept.Description:
One of the Oxford Dictionaries definitions of ACCOUNT is "a report or description of an event or experience".
An ACCOUNT then is a collection of information that relates to one or more EVENTs. Those EVENTs will have an ITEM in common in a role and thus the ACCOUNT becomes a history of information about that role.
Concept.Examples: * A Customer Account at a business * The history of a Building * Regular welfare payments to a claimant * A Medical History of a patient * Transactions that have been posted to a budget.

LogEntry.Change: Definition Reference for Oxford Dicitonaries. Set up Notes.
Remove reference to ROLE as a concept

Concept.Name: Agent
Concept.Definition: A PERSON, or ORGANIZATION, providing a SERVICE or taking a role in an EVENT
Concept.Description:
One of the definitions of AGENT at Oxford Dictionaries is "a person or thing that takes an active role or produces a specified effect".
AGENT is used to make relationships where the type of ITEM could be either a PERSON or an ORGANIZATION.
Concept.Examples: * Supplier * Applicant

Concept.Name: Agreement
Concept.Definition: A negotiated arrangement between AGENTs as to a course of action
Concept.Examples: * Contract * Memorandum of Understanding * Code of Connection

Concept.Name: Assumption
Concept.Definition: A predicted future STATE upon which DECISIONs are made.
Concept.Description: Assumptions about the future STATE of ITEM might be usefully shared across a city.
Concept.Examples: * forecast * extrapolation

Concept.Name: Building
Concept.Definition: A man-made OBJECT with roof and walls, with a fixed PLACE, intended for sheltering PERSONs or other OBJECTs.
Concept.Examples: * a House * a Factory * a Station * an Office

Concept.Name: Case
Concept.Definition: A container for information recording the history of EVENTS initiated by a SERVICE Demand.
Concept.Description: When a SERVICE is used, it typically raises a CASE where information is contained through to the resolution of the CASE.
Concept.Examples: * A Planning Application * An Incident of Fraud

Concept.Name: Collection
Concept.Definition: A grouping of ITEMS, as defined by an AGENT, that need to be managed, or operated upon together.
Concept.Description:
COLLECTIONs are defined by an AGENT.
The contents of a COLLECTION might be explicitly itemised, for example, a jewellery collection, or be defined by a coping statement, for example, the properties available for rent.
Concept.Examples: * Stock * Lamp Posts

Concept.Name: Community
Concept.Definition: A group of PERSONs and/or ORGANIZATIONs that share common characteristics such as PLACE, circumstance etc.
Concept.Description:
A Community is defined by an AGENT, in terms of the common characteristics of the PERSONs and/or ORGANIZATIONs that are contained in it.
The STATE of a COMMUNITY can be tracked without having to know the identity of each PERSON and ORGANIZATION.
A COMMUNITY might be composed of other COMMUNITYs. For example * the Business sector might be composed of the Industrial sector, the Tourism sector, the Financial Services sector etc. * the youth of a town are contained in the residents of a town.
The actual PERSONs or ORGANIZATIONs might change without changing the identity of a COMMUNITY, for example the 'Long Term Unemployed in a City' remains the same COMMUNITY even though some people have left it, and others have joined it.
Members of a COMMUNITY do not need to be aware of each other, and are not acting with a collective goal. If they are, then they are an ORGANISATION. For example, 'Long Term Unemployed', is a COMMUNITY, whereas 'The Job Seekers Club', is an ORGANIZATION.
Concept.Examples:
* Residents of a City or Town * Commuters * Carers * Long Term Unemployed * Low Income Families
* The Tourism Industry * The Retail Sector

LogEntry.Change: Definition now refers to PLACE instead of LOCATION
Improved Notes. Link to Oxford Dictionaries

Concept.Name: Decision
Concept.Definition: A conclusion or resolution reached after consideration
Concept.Description: A DECISION is the outcome of an EVENT, and not the event itself. A DECISION, taken by an AGENT, will have an effect on a number of ITEMs, and will be influenced by OBJECTIVEs.
Concept.Examples: * To provide RESOURCEs * To agree a PLAN

Concept.Name: Event
Concept.Definition: An occurrence that has or might happen over a period of time.
Concept.Description:
An EVENT will refer to a number of ITEMs which will take roles in the EVENT.
So, for example, a PERSON may take the role 'applicant', in one EVENT, and the same person may take the role 'patient', in another EVENT.
All types of ITEM can take roles in an EVENT, so for example * a candlestick as an OBJECT could be the murder weapon in a crime EVENT. * a tender as an ABSTRACT could be the subject of a contract signing EVENT.
An EVENT might occur over a very short period of time, e.g. a lightening flash, or a very long period of time, e.g. formation of the continents.
Concept.Examples: * an accident * a birth * an application for a service

Concept.Name: Function
Concept.Definition: A COLLECTION of SERVICEs
Concept.Description:
A FUNCTION might be made up of SERVICEs from many ORGANIZATIONs.
A SERVICE might appear in many FUNCTIONs.
A FUNCTION might be defined to * bring together the SERVICES that are relevant to a COMMUNITY, and/or a PLACE; * combine SERVICES for accounting purposes.
The United Nations provide a category list of the Functions of Government at http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/regcst.asp?Cl=4.
Concept.Examples: * Education * Waste Management * Translation Services

Concept.Name: Item
Concept.Definition: An individual article or unit, especially one that is part of a list, collection, or set.
Concept.Description:
Most Items, can be associated with a PLACE.
ITEMs have STATE ( conditions or circumstances ), which can change over time.
Usually, data will refer directly to a sub-concept of ITEM
* OBJECT * PERSON * ORGANIZATION * COMMUNITY * ABSTRACT
Concept.Examples: See sub-concepts for examples

LogEntry.Change: Name changes from Entity to Item, as we are using the term Entity to refer to all things that have a distinct and separate existence.

Concept.Name: Method
Concept.Definition: A pre-determined procedure, or series of steps, designed to accomplish an OBJECTIVE.
Concept.Description: A number of METHODs might be associated with a SERVICE as options for achieving an OBJECTIVE.
Concept.Examples: * payment method * customer contact method * debt recovery method * medical procedure * an MOT procedure

Concept.Name: Metric
Concept.Definition: A measure of demography, characteristics, activity or performance
Concept.Description: METRICs are often collected as statistics which describe the STATE of a SERVICE, COMMUNITY, or PLACE.
Concept.Examples: * Performance Indicator * Deprivation Index * Traffic Count

Concept.Name: Object
Concept.Definition: A physical ITEM
Concept.Description: Objects are the 'things' that are contained in a City.
Concept.Examples: * a Building * a Road * a Car * a Lamppost

Concept.Name: Objective
Concept.Definition: An achievement desired by an AGENT.
Concept.Description:
An OBJECTIVE refers to a desired change of condition or circumstances of something (an ITEM). Where the change can be quantified, the OBJECTIVE might be linked to one or more TARGETs.
Where OBJECTIVEs are set for a COMMUNITY, the desire might be to change the size of the community, or the well-being of the PERSONs or ORGANIZATIONS in it.
Concept.Examples: * Create new jobs in the Energy sector. * Reduce Carbon Emissions in a city by 25% within 5 years.

LogEntry.Change: Improve definition to refer to an AGENT. Link to Oxford Dictionaries.

Concept.Name: Observation
Concept.Definition: An EVENT in which a STATE is recorded.
Concept.Description: The Open Geospatial Consortium define an observation as "an act at a discrete instant or period, through which a number or term is assigned to a phenomenon using a procedure, such as a sensor, instrument, or algorithm."
Concept.Examples: * Sensor Reading * Medical Assessment

Concept.Name: Organization
Concept.Definition: A group of PERSONs with a collective goal.
Concept.Examples: * A business * A public sector body * A charity * A household

Concept.Name: Person
Concept.Definition: An individual human being.

LogEntry.Change: Link to definition from Oxford Dictionaries. Refine the Notes.

Concept.Name: Place
Concept.Definition: A geographic position, area, or volume.
Concept.Description: A Place might have definite or indefinite boundaries.
Concept.Examples: * a point defined by coordinates, e.g. the location of an incident * an area defined by a set of coordinates, e.g. a school catchment area * a place referred to only by a name without attempting to define the area exactly e.g. a Town

Concept.Name: Plan
Concept.Definition: A list of steps with times and RESOURCEs, used to achieve an OBJECTIVE.
Concept.Description: A PLAN will have been devised to achieve an OBJECTIVE, over a period of time.
Concept.Examples: * Corporate Plan * Community Plan * Marketing Plan * Project Plan * Strategy

LogEntry.Change: Add TIME to the definition. Link to Oxford Dictionaries definition

Concept.Name: Resource
Concept.Definition: An ITEM that can be drawn on by an AGENT to produce a benefit.
Concept.Description:
RESOURCES are available to an AGENT to allocate to SERVICEs and PLANs to achieve OBJECTIVEs.
Typically RESOURCES can be money, materials, staff, and assets.
Concept.Examples: * materials * money * staff * assets

LogEntry.Change: Add notes. Link to Oxford Dicitonaries for definition.

Concept.Name: Rule
Concept.Definition: an explicit or understood regulation or principle governing conduct or procedure within a particular area of activity
Concept.Description: RULEs can constrain the design of SERVICEs.
Concept.Examples: * Legislation * Eligibility * Principle * Policy

Concept.Name: Service
Concept.Definition: The capacity to carry out one or more METHODs.
Concept.Description:
A SERVICE exists even if it is not accessed. For example, an Advice Hotline exists as a SERVICE even if nobody calls it.
SERVICEs are typically targeted at COMMUNITYs.
SERVICEs can consume RESOURCEs and give benefit.
A CASE contains information about an instance of a use of a SERVICE.
Concept.Examples: * a hairdressing service * a street cleaning service * an energy supply * an advice service

Concept.Name: State
Concept.Definition: A circumstance or condition of an ITEM at a time.
Concept.Description:
An ITEM might have a series of STATEs describing condition or circumstance, at particular times.
For example A PERSON might be 'unemployed' in June and 'employed' in July.
Changes to STATE are often the outcome of EVENTs.
Concept.Examples: * Income * Housing * Repair *

Concept.Name: Target
Concept.Definition: A desired STATE
Concept.Description:
A TARGET will provide a value at a time in the future, for a STATE. TARGETs are linked to OBJECTIVEs which in turn links to the AGENT that has set the TARGET.
An OBJECTIVE might have many TARGETs over time, and a TARGET might relate to many OBJECTIVEs.

View.Name: Items
View.Description:
A city will contain lots of ITEMs, which might be referred to in data from many organisations. Where a city can agree a common identifier for an ITEM, many organisations can provide information about it.
Most obviously, an ITEM might be an OBJECT such as a lamppost, a building, or a road, but an ITEM might also be
* an ORGANIZATION, such as a local council, or an energy supplier * a PERSON, such as a resident or user of a service. * a COMMUNITY, such as commuters, or low income families
The model contains sub-concepts of ITEM for these. The relationships that are defined for ITEM are therefore also true for these sub-concepts.
The AGENT concept can be used where it is not possible to know if data refers to a PERSON or an ORGANIZATION.
A city will also need to refer to non-physical things such as a service, a contract, a decision, or a case. These non-physical things are also ITEMs, and the model uses the sub-concept ABSTRACT to group them together. A number of further sub-concepts within ABSTRACT are defined in the model.
ITEMs might be associated with PLACEs; most obviously, to describe where an ITEM is. Although ABSTRACT ITEMs don't have a physical existence, they can still be related to PLACE, perhaps to describe their coverage.
PLACE is used to describe a geographic position or area. Some PLACEs will be described precisely with coordinates, and boundaries, while others will be less precise, perhaps just with a locality name.
Both ITEMs and PLACEs can have a series of STATEs over time. Typically, a STATE describes the condition of an ITEM or PLACE.
A STATE might be described subjectively, from the point of view of an observer, for example, 'the building condition is poor'. A STATE might also be described quantitively, for example, the temperature of a room, or perhaps as a statistic, for example "a community's deprivation index".
A Smart City will base its decisions on a shared understanding of the STATE of ITEMS, either in real-time, or by implementing PLANs to being about changes to STATEs.

View.Name: Collections of Items
View.Description:
ITEMs are often grouped together so that they can be managed, or operated upon together. For example
* Housing Stock * Vehicle Fleet * Manholes * Roads * a Contracts Register
COLLECTIONs are defined by AGENTs so that the actual contents are either explicitly listed, or defined by a scoping statement.
COLLECTIONs enable lists of ITEMs to be defined, created and shared across a city.
Although the contents of a COLLECTION can be physical ITEMs, a COLLECTION is an ABSTRACT ITEM.
As a COLLECTION is itself, a sub-concept of ITEM, it's STATE can be described and tracked over time.

View.Name: Events
View.Description:
For a city, events might include
* an incident * a measurement * a change of a setting * a transaction * a use of a service
… and so on.
An EVENT will refer to a number of ITEMs which will take roles in the EVENT.
So, for example, a PERSON may take the role 'applicant', in one EVENT, and the same person may take the role 'patient', in another EVENT.
All types of ITEM can take roles in an EVENT, so for example * a candlestick as an OBJECT could be the murder weapon in a crime EVENT. * a tender as an ABSTRACT could be the subject of a contract signing EVENT.
EVENTs occur over a period of time, and might cause a change in the STATE of a number of ITEMs.
For example, a driver convicted of speeding might cause a change to the number of points on a driving licence, or to the eligibility to drive.

View.Name: Objectives
View.Description:
ORGANIZATIONs and individual PEOPLE will have a series of OBJECTIVEs setting their reasoning and ambition for the changes that they desire. Some of these might be long term, for example
* providing suitable housing * reducing carbon emissions * reducing unemployment
, while others might be more immediate or real-time such as
* optimum energy usage * maintaining safe water levels
The model combines the concepts of PERSON and ORGANISATION into the concept of AGENT. This simplifies the relationships that would often otherwise need to refer to either.
Where an OBJECTIVE can be quantified, it can be linked to a series of TARGETs which are the observable STATEs of the impacted ITEMs.
OBJECTIVEs might be set on the basis of a series of ASSUMPTIONs, which capture a predicted future STATE of one of more ITEMs. The gap between an ASSUMPTION and a TARGET might define the change that is sought by the OBJECTIVE.
For example * COLLECTION - houses for rent under £400 per week * TARGET - 10,000 by 2016 * OBJECTIVE - provide adequate affordable housing * ASSUMPTION -10,000 households will require affordable housing by 2016
METRICs are regularly published which track the actual STATE of an ITEM, and can be used to consider if TARGETs have been achieved.

View.Name: Observing and Responding
View.Description:
A city might have a series of automated SERVICEs that respond in real-time to observed STATEs, to adjust settings to re-establish an optimum STATE.
For example, sensors and actuators can be used to * manage traffic flows * control temperatures * reduce energy consumption
8.5.3. The model represents a sensor as an OBJECT ITEM, which can be related to a PLACE describe where it is.
This view depicts three stages:
* determining objectives, and optimum states of system * readings be taken by a sensor; * a service responding to inputs by changing settings
For the first stage, the system is represented as an ITEM, for which one or more TARGET states can be defined.
For the second stage, a sensor takes a reading of the system, which is represented as an OBSERVATION EVENT capturing the STATE of an ITEM.
For the third stage, a further device or actuator might then be configured to automatically react to an observed STATE by changing settings.
The actuator is also an OBJECT, which has a role in an EVENT that changes a STATE. The change of settings is a SERVICE, implementing a METHOD, provided by an AGENT. A log of the observations, and settings is recorded in a CASE.
So for example,
stage 1 - an optimum temperature (TARGET) of a room (ITEM) can be set to reduce energy consumption ( OBJECTIVE ).
stage 2 - a temperature sensor (OBJECT) might take a reading (OBSERVATION) of the temperature (STATE) of the room.
stage 3 - a service (SERVICE) instructs (EVENT) the actuator (OBJECT) to change the valve setting (STATE) of a radiator (OBJECT). The impact of the change is then monitored via further observations recorded within the CASE

View.Name: Services
View.Description:
For a city, SERVICEs might include
* energy provision * waste collection * licensing * car parking * removing abandoned vehicles and so on.
A SERVICE is the responsibility of an ORGANIZATION or an individual PERSON. The concepts of ORGANIZATION and PERSON are combined into the concept AGENT.
The AGENT providing a SERVICE is not necessarily the same as the AGENT responsible for it.
A SERVICE will be targeted for use by a COMMUNITY which might be, for example * the residents of a city * the long term unemployed * commuters * families and so on.
As both COMMUNITY, and SERVICE are sub-concepts of ITEM, their STATEs can be recorded over time. For SERVICE, this enables actual and TARGET values to be recorded for throughput and performance, for example: * the number of abandoned vehicles reported over a period * the average time taken to remove a vehicle
SERVICEs are often constrained by RULES such as * legislation * eligibility * terms and conditions and so on
A SERVICE implements one or more METHODs, which might be re-used in other SERVICEs.
SERVICEs from many AGENTs can be grouped together into FUNCTIONs. FUNCTION is a sub-concept of COLLECTION.
A FUNCTION can list the services that serve a particular COMMUNITY, for example
* Waste Management (FUNCTION) might contain SERVICEs for 'Refuse Collection', 'Recycling', 'Waste Disposal', and those SERVICEs might be provided from many ORGANISATIONs in the city.

View.Name: Cases
View.Description:
A CASE is raised when a SERVICE is used.
For a city, a case might be
* a crime investigation * a planning application * rectifying a fault on a network and so on.
A CASE contains the EVENTs that are relevant to an individual use of a SERVICE, until the CASE is closed.
For some CASEs, a PLAN might be devised giving estimated times and RESOURCEs for future EVENTs.
An AGENT might maintain a series of ACCOUNTs, that contain a history of EVENTs that apply to one or more ITEMs, for example * a medical history * a customer history * a criminal record * a building maintenance record and so on.

View.Name: Plans
View.Description:
A PLAN records the steps and decision points that will be applied to achieve a TARGET STATE of an ITEM or PLACE, as a part of addressing an OBJECTIVE.
A Plan might be derived from existing METHODs which have been devised to achieve the desired outcome.
As a PLAN is enacted, EVENTs will occur that record the actual happenings as compared to those planned.
A city might wish to discover and track the PLANS from many AGENTs that apply to OBJECTIVEs for ITEMs or PLACEs.

View.Name: Resources and Decisions
View.Description:
RESOURCEs are ITEMs that can be put to a use, for a benefit.
RESOURCEs can be allocated to a SERVICE or a PLAN.
AGENTs take DECISIONs about ITEMs which are influenced by OBJECTIVEs. A DECISION can be about the application of a RESOURCE.
A city might wish to engage stakeholders about DECISION, and particularly about how RESOURCEs are allocated over SERVICEs and PLANs to achieve OBJECTIVEs.
